member.name: T:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1
member.summary: A simple data structure to manage an array as a circular buffer.
member.remarks:
This class provides simple methods for abstracting a circular buffer. A circular buffer allows for faster access of data by avoiding potential copy operations for data that is at the beginning.
Stream data structures can benefit from this data structure by allocating a single block on the heap of an arbitrary size. If the stream is long-lived the benefits are larger. In the .NET framework (4.0 and earlier), all allocations of data structures that are 80kb and larger are automatically allocated on the heap. The heap is not garbage collected like smaller objects. Instead, new elements are added to the heap in an incremental fashion. It is theoretically possible to exhaust all memory in an application by allocating and deallocating regularly on a heap if such a new heap element requires space and there is not a single block large enough. By using the with the type T as byte, you can preallocate a buffer for a stream of any reasonable size (as a simple example 5MB). That block is allocated once and remains for the lifetime of the stream. No time will be allocated for compacting or garbage collection.
member.typeparam: Type to use for the array.

member.remarks: The array is used as the storage for the circular buffer. No copy of the array is made, only a reference. The is defined to be the first entry in the circular buffer. This may be any value from zero to the last index ( Array.Length - 1). The value is the amount of data in the array, and it may cause wrapping (so that by setting offset near the end, a value of count may be set so that data can be considered at the end and beginning of the array given).

member.name: P:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.WriteLength
member.summary: Get length of continuous available space from the current position to the end of the array or until the buffer is full.
member.remarks:
This function is useful if you need to pass the array to another function that will then fill the contents of the buffer. You would pass as the offset for where writing the data should start, and WriteLength as the length of buffer space available until the end of the array buffer. After the read operation that writes in to your buffer, the array is completely full, or until the end of the array.
Such a property is necessary in case that the free space wraps around the buffer. Where below X is your stream you wish to read from, b is the circular buffer instantiated as the type CircularBuffer{T}.
c = X.Read(b.Array, b.End, b.WriteLength); b.Produce(c);
If the property WriteLength is not zero, then there is space in the buffer to read data.

member.name: P:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.ReadLength
member.summary: Get the length of the continuous amount of data that can be read in a single copy operation from the start of the buffer data.
member.remarks: This function is useful if you need to pass the array to another function that will use the contents of the array. You would pass as the offset for reading data and as the count. Then based on the amount of data operated on, you would free space with (ReadLength).

member.name: M:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.GetReadBlock(System.Int32)
member.summary: Given an offset, calculate the length of data that can be read until the end of the block.
member.param: The offset into the circular buffer to test for the read length.
member.returns: Length of the block that can be read from .
member.exception: The may not be negative.
member.remarks:
Similar to the property ReadLength, this function takes an argument offset which is used to determine the length of data that can be read from that offset, until either the end of the block, or the end of the buffer.
This function is useful if you want to read a block of data, not starting from the offset 0 (and you don't want to consume the data before hand to reach an offset of zero).
The example below, will calculate a checksum from the third byte in the block for the length of data. If the block to read from offset 3 can be done in one operation, it will do so. Else it must be done in two operations, first from offset 3 to the end, then from offset 0 for the remaining data.

member.name: M:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.Consume(System.Int32)
member.summary: Consume array elements (freeing space from the beginning) updating pointers in the circular buffer.
member.param: Amount of data to consume.
member.exception: is negative, or cannot consume more data than exists.
member.remarks: This method advances the internal pointers for Start based on the length that should be consumed. The pointer End does not change. It is important that this method does not Reset() the buffer in case that all data is consumed. A common scenario with Streams is to write into the buffer using asynchronous I/O. If a Reset() occurs during an asynchronous I/O ReadFile(), the End pointer is also changed, so that when a Produce() occurs on completion of the ReadFile() operation, the pointers are updated, but not using the pointers before the Reset(). No crash would occur (so long as the underlying array is pinned), but data corruption would occur if this method were not used in this particular scenario.

member.name: M:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.Produce(System.Int32)
member.summary: Produce bytes (allocating space at the end) updating pointers in the circular buffer.
member.param: The number of bytes to indicate that have been added from the index to the end of the array and possibly again from the start of the array if overlapped.
member.exception: Cannot produce negative , or producing exceeds .

member.name: M:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer`1.Revert(System.Int32)
member.summary: Revert elements produced to the end of the circular buffer.
member.param: The number of bytes to remove from the end of the array, moving the property to the left, leaving the property untouched.
member.exception: The must be positive and not exceed the number of elements in the circular buffer.
member.remarks: This method can be used to remove data that has been added to the end of the circular buffer. When using this data structure for streams, you would not use this property to ensure consistency of your stream (your Read operation would consume from your circular buffer and Write would produce data to your circular buffer.

member.name: M:RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBufferExtensions.Convert(System.Text.Decoder,RJCP.Datastructures.CircularBuffer{System.Byte},System.Char[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Use a decoder to convert from a Circular Buffer of bytes into a char array.
member.param: The decoder to do the conversion.
The circular buffer of bytes to convert from.
An array to store the converted characters.
The first element of chars in which data is stored.
Maximum number of characters to write.
to indicate that no further data is to be converted; otherwise, .
When this method returns, contains the number of bytes that were used in the conversion. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
When this method returns, contains the number of characters from chars that were produced by the conversion. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
When this method returns, contains if all the characters specified by byteCount were converted; otherwise, . This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.exception: The output buffer is too small to contain any of the converted input.
or may not be .
member.remarks:
This method should behave the same as the decoder for an array of bytes of equal size.
The completed output parameter indicates whether all the data in the input buffer was converted and stored in the output buffer. This parameter is set to if the number of bytes specified by the bytes.Length parameter cannot be converted without exceeding the number of characters specified by the charCount parameter.
The completed parameter can also be set to , even though the all bytes were consumed. This situation occurs if there is still data in the Decoder object that has not been stored in the bytes buffer.
There are a few noted deviations from using the Decoder on an array of bytes, instead of a Circular Buffer.
When converting a sequence of bytes to multiple chars, if those sequences result in the minimum number of characters being written as 2 or more characters, slight discrepancies occur. A UTF8 decoder would convert the sequence F3 A0 82 84 to the two characters DB40 DC84. The UTF8 decoder would not consume any of the 4 bytes if all 4 bytes are immediately available to a single call to the Decoder.Convert() function and instead raise an exception. This Convert() function may consume some of these bytes and indicate success, if the byte sequence wraps over from the end of the array to the beginning of the array. The number of bytes consumed (bytesUsed) is correct and characters produced (charsUsed) is also correct. There is no error found according to the MS documentation. The next call will result in an exception instead. So this function may: consume more bytes than expected (but with the correct results); and may not raise an exception immediately if those bytes were consumed.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.PortName
member.summary: Gets the port for communications, including but not limited to all available COM ports.
member.remarks:
A list of valid port names can be obtained using the GetPortNames method.
When changing the port name, and the property UpdateOnPortSet is , setting this property will cause the port to be opened, status read and the port then closed. Thus, you can use this behaviour to determine the actual settings of the port (which remain constant until a program actually changes the port settings).
Setting this property to itself, while having UpdateOnPortSet to has the effect of updating the local properties based on the current port settings.

member.remarks: The property tracks whether the port is open for use by the caller, not whether the port is open by any application on the machine.
member.value: if the serial port is open; otherwise, . The default is .

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Encoding

member.remarks: The encoding is used for encoding string information to byte format when sending over the serial port, or receiving data via the serial port. It is only used with the read/write functions that accept strings (and not used for byte based reading and writing).

member.summary: Specify the driver In Queue at the time it is opened.
member.remarks: This provides the driver a recommended internal input buffer, in bytes.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.DriverOutQueue
member.summary: Specify the driver Out Queue at the time it is opened.
member.remarks: This provides the driver a recommended internal output buffer, in bytes.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.CanTimeout
member.summary: Gets a value that determines whether the current stream can time out.
member.returns: A value that determines whether the current stream can time out in milliseconds.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.CanRead
member.summary: Check if this stream supports reading.
member.remarks: Supported so long as the stream is not disposed.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ReadTimeout
member.summary: Define the time out when reading data from the stream.
member.remarks:
This defines the time out when data arrives in the buffered memory of this stream, that is, when the driver indicates that data has arrived to the application.
Should the user perform a read operation and no data is available to copy in the buffer, a time out will occur.
Set this property to for an infinite time out.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ReadBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the SerialPortStream input buffer.
member.remarks:
Sets the amount of buffering to use when reading data from the serial port. Data is read locally into this buffered stream through another port.
The Microsoft implementation uses this to set the buffer size of the underlying driver. This implementation interprets the ReadBufferSize differently by setting the local buffer which can be much larger (megabytes) and independent of the low level driver.
member.exception: An attempt was used to change the size of the buffer while the port is open (and therefore buffering is active).

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ReceivedBytesThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of bytes in the read buffer before a DataReceived event occurs.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.BytesToRead
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes of data in the receive buffer.
member.remarks:
This method returns the number of bytes available in the input read buffer. Bytes that are cached by the driver itself are not accounted for, as they haven't yet been read by the local thread.
This has the effect, that if the local buffer is full (let's say that it is arbitrarily picked to be 64KB) and the local driver also has buffered 4KB, only the size of the local buffer is given, so 64KB (instead of the expected 68KB).

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Check if this stream supports writing.
member.remarks: Supported so long as the stream is not disposed.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.WriteTimeout
member.summary: Define the time out when writing data to the local buffer.
member.remarks:
This defines the time out when writing data to the local buffer. No guarantees are given to when the data will actually be transferred over to the serial port as this is dependent on the hardware configuration and flow control.
When writing data to the stream buffer, a time out will occur if not all data can be written to the local buffer and the buffer wasn't able to empty itself in the period given by the time out.
Naturally then, this depends on the size of the send buffer in use, how much data is already in the buffer, how fast the data can leave the buffer.
In case the data cannot be written to the buffer in the given time out, no data will be written at all.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.WriteBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the serial port output buffer.
member.remarks:
Defines the size of the buffered stream write buffer, used to send data to the serial port. It does not affect the buffers in the serial port hardware itself.
The Microsoft implementation uses this to set the buffer size of the underlying driver. This implementation interprets the WriteBufferSize differently by setting the local buffer which can be much larger (megabytes) and independent of the low level driver.
member.exception: An attempt was used to change the size of the buffer while the port is open (and therefore buffering is active).

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.BytesToWrite
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes of data in the send buffer.
member.remarks: The send buffer includes the serial driver's send buffer as well as internal buffering in the itself.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.CDHolding
member.summary: Gets the state of the Carrier Detect line for the port.
member.remarks:
This property can be used to monitor the state of the carrier detection line for a port. No carrier usually indicates that the receiver has hung up and the carrier has been dropped.
Windows documentation sometimes refers to the Carrier Detect line as the RLSD (Receive Line Signal Detect).

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.CtsHolding
member.summary: Gets the state of the Clear-to-Send line.
member.remarks: The Clear-to-Send (CTS) line is used in Request to Send/Clear to Send (RTS/CTS) hardware handshaking. The CTS line is queried by a port before data is sent.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.DsrHolding
member.summary: Gets the state of the Data Set Ready (DSR) signal.
member.remarks: This property is used in Data Set Ready/Data Terminal Ready (DSR/DTR) handshaking. The Data Set Ready (DSR) signal is usually sent by a modem to a port to indicate that it is ready for data transmission or data reception.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.RingHolding
member.summary: Gets the state of the Ring line signal.
member.remarks: The ring line is a separate line from a modem that indicates if there is an incoming call.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.BaudRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the serial baud rate.
member.remarks:
The stream doesn't impose any arbitrary limits on setting the baud rate. It is passed directly to the driver and it is up to the driver to determine if the baud rate is settable or not. Normally, a driver will attempt to set a baud rate that is within 5% of the requested baud rate (but not guaranteed).
If the serial driver doesn't support setting the baud rate, setting this property is silently ignored and the baud rate isn't updated.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.DataBits
member.summary: Gets or sets the standard length of data bits per byte.
member.remarks:
The range of values for this property is from 5 through 8 and 16. A check is made by setting this property against the advertised capabilities of the driver. That is, a driver lists its capabilities to say what byte sizes it can support. If the driver cannot support the byte size requested, an exception is raised.
Not all possible combinations are allowed by all drivers. That implies, that an exception may be raised for a valid setting of the DataBits property, if the other parameters are not valid. Such an example might be that 5-bits are only supported with 2 stop bits and not otherwise. The driver itself will raise an exception to the application in this case.
If the serial driver doesn't support setting the data bits, setting this property is silently ignored and the number of data bits isn't updated.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.StopBits
member.summary: Gets or sets the standard number of stop bits per byte.
member.remarks: Gets or sets the stop bits that should be used when transmitting and receiving data over the serial port. If the serial driver doesn't support setting the stop bits, setting this property is silently ignored and the number of stop bits isn't updated.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Parity
member.summary: Gets or sets the parity-checking protocol.
member.remarks: Parity is an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the same — either even or odd — for each group of bits that is transmitted without error. In modem-to-modem communications, parity is often one of the parameters that must be agreed upon by sending parties and receiving parties before transmission can take place.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ParityReplace
member.summary: Gets or sets the byte that replaces invalid bytes in a data stream when a parity error occurs.
member.remarks: If the value is set to the nul character, parity replacement is disabled. This property only has an effect if the property is not .

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.DiscardNull
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether null bytes are ignored when transmitted between the port and the receive buffer.
member.remarks: This value should normally be set to , especially for binary transmissions. Setting this property to can cause unexpected results for UTF32- and UTF16-encoded bytes.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.DtrEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables the Data Terminal Ready (DTR) signal during serial communication.
member.remarks: Data Terminal Ready (DTR) is typically enabled during XON/XOFF software handshaking and Request to Send/Clear to Send (RTS/CTS) hardware handshaking, and modem communications.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.RtsEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Request to Send (RTS) signal is enabled during serial communication.
member.remarks:
The Request to Transmit (RTS) signal is typically used in Request to Send/Clear to Send (RTS/CTS) hardware handshaking.
Note, the windows feature RTS_CONTROL_TOGGLE is not supported by this class.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Handshake
member.summary: Gets or sets the handshaking protocol for serial port transmission of data.
member.remarks:
Enables handshaking on the serial port. We support three types of handshaking: RTS/CTS; XON/XOFF; and DTR/DTS. The Microsoft implementation SerialPort only supports RTS/CTS and XON/XOFF.
This method is not 100% compatible with the Microsoft implementation. By disabling RTS flow control, it sets behaviour so that the RTS line is enabled. You must set the property as appropriate. Although the Microsoft implementation doesn't support DSR/DTR at all, setting this property will also set the DTR line to enabled. You must set the property as appropriate.
When enabling DTR flow control, the DsrSensitivity flag is set, so the driver ignores any bytes received, unless the DSR modem input line is high. Otherwise, if DTR flow control is disabled, the DSR line is ignored. For more detailed information about how windows works with flow control, see the site: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms810467.aspx. When DTR flow control is specified, the fOutxDsrFlow is set along with fDsrSensitivity.
Note, the windows feature RTS_CONTROL_TOGGLE is not supported by this class. This is also not supported by the Microsoft implementation.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.XOnLimit
member.summary: Define the limit of actual bytes in the transmit buffer when XON is sent.
member.remarks: The XOFF character (19 or ^S) is sent when the input buffer comes within bytes of being full, and the XON character (17 or ^Q) is sent when the input buffer comes within bytes of being empty.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.XOffLimit
member.summary: Define the limit of free bytes in the buffer before XOFF is sent.
member.remarks: The XOFF character (19 or ^S) is sent when the input buffer comes within bytes of being full, and the XON character (17 or ^Q) is sent when the input buffer comes within bytes of being empty.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.TxContinueOnXOff
member.summary: Enable or Disable transmit of data when software flow control is enabled.
member.remarks:
MSDN documentation states this flag as follows:
If this member is , transmission continues after the input buffer has come within bytes of being full and the driver has transmitted the XoffChar character to stop receiving bytes. If this member is , transmission does not continue until the input buffer is within XonLim bytes of being empty and the driver has transmitted the XonChar character to resume reception.
When the driver buffer fills up and sends the XOFF character (and software flow control is active), this property defines if the driver should continue to send data over the serial port or not.
The Microsoft SerialPort implementation doesn't provide this option (in fact, in .NET 4.0 it doesn't appear to control this at all).
Some DCE devices will resume sending after any character arrives. The member should be set to when communicating with a DCE device that resumes sending after any character arrives.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.BreakState
member.summary: Gets or sets the break signal state.
member.remarks: The break signal state occurs when a transmission is suspended and the line is placed in a break state (all low, no stop bit) until released. To enter a break state, set this property to . If the port is already in a break state, setting this property again to does not result in an exception. It is not possible to write to the while is .

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Open
member.summary: Opens a new serial port connection.
member.exception: This object is already managing a serial port connection.
SerialPortStream is disposed of.
member.remarks:
Opens a connection to the serial port provided by the constructor or the Port property. If this object is already managing a serial port, this object raises an exception.
When opening the port, only the settings explicitly applied will be given to the port. That is, if you read the default BaudRate as 115200, this value will only be applied if you explicitly set it to 115200. Else the default baud rate of the serial port when its opened will be used.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.OpenDirect
member.summary: Opens a new serial port connection with control if the port settings are initialised or not.
member.exception: SerialPortStream is disposed of.
Serial Port already opened
member.remarks:
Opens a connection to the serial port provided by the constructor or the property. If this object is already managing a serial port, this object raises an exception.
You can override the open so that no communication settings are retrieved or set. This is useful for virtual COM ports that do not manage state bits (some as some emulated COM ports or USB based communications that present themselves as a COM port but do not have any underlying physical RS232 implementation).
If you use this method to avoid setting parameters for the serial port, instead only to open the serial port, you should be careful not to set any properties associated with the serial port, as they will set the communications properties.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Close
member.summary: Closes the port connection, sets the property to . Does not dispose the object.
member.remarks: This method will clean up the object so far as to close the port. Internal buffers remain active that the stream can continue to read. Writes will throw an exception.

member.summary: Reads up to the NewLine value in the input buffer.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ReadTo(System.String)
member.summary: Reads a string up to the specified text in the input buffer.
member.remarks:
The ReadTo() function will read text from the byte buffer up to a predetermined limit (1024 characters) when looking for the string . If is not found within this limit, data is thrown away and more data is read (effectively consuming the earlier bytes).
This method is provided as compatibility with the Microsoft implementation. There are some important differences however. This method attempts to fix a minor pathological problem with the Microsoft implementation. If the string is not found, the MS implementation may modify the internal state of the decoder. As a workaround, it pushes all decoded characters back into its internal byte buffer, which fixes the problem that a second call to the ReadTo() method returns the consistent results, but a call to Read(byte[], ..) may return data that was not actually transmitted by the DCE. This would happen in case that an invalid byte sequence was found, converted to a fall back character. The original byte sequence is removed and replaced with the byte equivalent of the fall back character.
This method is rather slow, because it tries to preserve the byte buffer in case of failure.
In case the data cannot be read, an exception is always thrown. So you may assume that if this method returns, you have valid data.
member.param: The text to indicate where the read operation stops.
member.returns: The contents of the input buffer up to the specified .
member.exception: Data was not available in the timeout specified.
Device Error (e.g. device removed).

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.ReadExisting
member.summary: Reads all immediately available bytes.
member.remarks:
Reads all data in the current buffer. If there is no data available, then no data is returned. This is different to the Microsoft implementation, that will read all data, and if there is no data, then it waits for data based on the time outs. This method employs no time outs.
Because this method returns only the data that is currently in the cached buffer and ignores the data that is actually buffered by the driver itself, there may be a slight discrepancy between the value returned by BytesToRead and the actual length of the string returned.
This method differs slightly from the Microsoft implementation in that this function doesn't initiate a read operation, as we have a dedicated thread to reading data that is running independently.
member.returns: The contents of the stream and the input buffer of the .

member.summary: Clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be written to the underlying device.
member.exception: Object is disposed, or disposed during flush operation.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.ISerialPortStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write the given data into the buffered serial stream for sending over the serial port.
member.param: The buffer containing data to send.
Offset into the array buffer where data begins.
Number of bytes to copy into the local buffer.
member.exception: Not enough buffer space was made available before the time out expired.
Object is disposed, or disposed during flush operation.
buffer was provided.
Negative offset or negative count provided.
Offset and count exceed buffer boundaries.
Serial port not open.
Serial Port was closed during the flush operation; or there was a device error.
member.remarks:
Data is copied from the array provided into the local stream buffer. It does not guarantee that data will be sent over the serial port. So long as there is enough local buffer space to accept the write of count bytes, this function will succeed. In case that the buffered serial stream doesn't have enough data, the function will wait up to milliseconds for enough buffer data to become available. In case that there is not enough space before the write time out expires, no data is copied to the local stream and the function fails with an exception.
For reliability, this function will only write data to the write buffer if the complete set of data requested can be written. This implies that the parameter be less or equal to the number of bytes that are available in the write buffer. Equivalently, you must make sure that you have a write buffer with at least allocated bytes or this function will always raise an exception.

The result value can be less than the number of bytes requested if the number of bytes currently available is less than the requested number, or it can be 0 (zero) if the end of the stream has been reached.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.ISerialBufferSerialData.TxEmptyEvent
member.summary: Indicates that the write buffer is now empty.
member.returns: if the write buffer is empty.
member.remarks:
Systems that return immediately after a Write before the write has been sent over the wire should call this method when the hardware indicates that data is flushed.
Systems that only return from the Write when data is completely written, or that do not receive events when the hardware buffer is empty, should call this method immediately after the Write is done.
Typically Windows systems may return before the hardware buffer is completely empty, where they notify later of an empty buffer with the EV_TXEMPTY event.

member.name: T:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.SerialBuffer
member.summary: Manages two buffers, for reading and writing, between a Stream and a Native Serial object.
member.remarks:
This class is used to help implement streams with time out functionality when the actual object that reads and writes data doesn't support streams, but simply reads and writes data using low level APIs.
It is to be expected that this object is only used by one reader and one writer. The reader and writer may be different threads. That is, the properties under SerialData are accessed only by one thread, the properties under StreamData are accessed only by one single (but may be different to SerialData) thread.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.SerialBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, where the buffer is not pinned.
member.param: The read buffer size in bytes.
The write buffer size in bytes.
member.remarks: Allocates buffer space for reading and writing (accessible via the and properties). The buffers are not pinned, meaning they should not be used for native methods (unless pinned explicitly).

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.SerialBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The read buffer size in bytes.
The write buffer size in bytes.
if set to then the read and write buffers are pinned.
member.remarks: Allocates buffer space for reading and writing (accessible via the and properties). If specified, the buffers can be pinned. THis causes the buffers to not move for the duration of the program. The usual warnings apply with pinning buffers, you must be careful to avoid memory problems as the GC will not be able to reallocate or free space. Note, you must pin the buffers if you intend to use overlapped I/O.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.DoWaitCommEvent(RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask@,System.Threading.NativeOverlapped@)
member.summary: Check if we should execute WaitCommEvent() and get the result if immediately available.
member.remarks:
This function abstracts the Win32 API WaitCommEvent(). It assumes overlapped I/O. Therefore, when calling this function, you should ensure that the parameter mask and overlap are pinned for the duration of the overlapped I/O. Any easy way to do this is to allocate the variables on the stack and then pass them by reference to this function.
You should not call this function if a pending I/O operation for WaitCommEvent() is still open. It is an error otherwise.
member.param: The mask value if information is available immediately.
The overlap structure to use.
member.returns: If the operation is pending or not.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.ProcessWaitCommEvent(RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask)
member.summary: Do work based on the mask event that has occurred.
member.param: The mask that was provided.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.DoReadEvent(System.Threading.NativeOverlapped@)
member.summary: Check if we should ReadFile() and process the data if serial data is immediately. available.
member.remarks: This function should be called if there is no existing pending read operation. It will check if there is data to read (indicated by the variable m_ReadByteAvailable, which is set by ProcessWaitCommEvent()) and then issue a ReadFile(). If the result indicates that asynchronous I/O is happening, true is returned. Else this function automatically calls ProcessReadEvent() with the number of bytes read. If an asynchronous operation is pending, then you should wait on the event in the overlapped structure not call this function until GetOverlappedResult() has been called.
member.param: The overlap structure to use for reading.
member.returns: If the operation is pending or not.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.ProcessReadEvent(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Produce the number of bytes read in the buffer.
member.remarks: If the number of bytes read is zero, this function should also be called, as it indicates that there are no more bytes pending. The recommendation from MS documentation for reading from the serial port indicates to read the buffer data, until a result of zero is given, which indicates to wait for the next receiving character.
member.param: Number of bytes read.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.DoWriteEvent(System.Threading.NativeOverlapped@)
member.summary: Check if we should WriteFile() and update buffers if serial data is immediately cached by driver.
member.remarks: This function should be called if there is no existing pending write operation. If the result indicates that asynchronous I/O is happening, true is returned. Else this function automatically calls ProcessWriteEvent() with the number of bytes written. If an asynchronous operation is pending, then you should wait on the event in the overlapped structure not call this function until GetOverlappedResult() has been called.
member.param: The overlap structure to use for writing.
member.returns: If the operation is pending or not.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommOverlappedIo.ProcessWriteEvent(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Consume the number of bytes written from the write buffer.
member.param: Number of bytes written to the driver.

member.name: T:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommState
member.summary: Abstracts the Win32 API GetCommState() and SetCommState().

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommState.#ctor(Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeFileHandle)
member.summary: Constructor for a DCB, prefilled with data from the handle provided.
member.remarks: This constructor allocates space for a DCB (Device Control Block) and gets the state of the serial port provided by the handle. You can then update the DCB with the properties of this class and set them with the SetCommState() method.
member.param: Valid handle to a serial port object.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommState.GetCommState
member.summary: Call Win32API to get the DCB for the current serial port object.
member.remarks: Calls the Win32 native API to get the DCB for the current serial port object. This assumes that the handle is valid. The Operating System will check the handle for validity. If there are problems, the IOException() exception will be raised.
member.exception: The DCB could not be obtained.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.CommState.SetCommState
member.summary: Call Win32API to set the DCB based on the current properties of this object.
member.remarks: Calls the Win32 native API to get the DCB for the current serial port object. This assumes that the handle is valid. The Operating System will check the handle for validity. If there are problems, the IOException() exception will be raised.
member.exception: The DCB could not be set. The reasons why the DCB cannot be set may be dependent on an invalid handle, or an invalid combination of data in the DCB.

member.summary: The right to write extended file attributes

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_EXECUTE
member.summary: For a native code file, the right to execute the file
member.remarks: This access right given to scripts may cause the script to be executable, depending on the script interpreter.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_TRAVERSE
member.summary: The right to traverse the directory
member.remarks: By default, users are assigned the BYPASS_TRAVERSE_CHECKING privilege, which ignores the FILE_TRAVERSE access right. See the remarks in "File Security and Access Rights" for more information

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_DELETE_CHILD
member.summary: The right to delete a directory and all the files it contains, including read-only files

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_READ_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: The right to read file attributes, for file, directory and pipe

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: FThe right to write file attributes

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_ALL_ACCESS
member.summary: All possible access rights for a file

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_GENERIC_READ
member.summary: Provide generic read access to a file

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_GENERIC_WRITE
member.summary: Provide generic write access to a file

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAccess.FILE_GENERIC_EXECUTE
member.summary: Provide generic execute access to a file

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileShare.FILE_SHARE_NONE
member.summary: Prevents other processes from opening a file or device if they request to delete, read or write access.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileShare.FILE_SHARE_READ
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request read access.
member.remarks: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request read access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the object if they request read access. If this flag is not specified, but the object has been opened for read access, the function fails.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileShare.FILE_SHARE_WRITE
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request write access.
member.remarks: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request write access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the object if they request write access. If this flag is not specified, but the object has been opened for write access, the function fails.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileShare.FILE_SHARE_DELETE
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request delete access.
member.remarks: Enables subsequent open operations on an object to request delete access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the object if they request delete access. If this flag is not specified, but the object has been opened for delete access, the function fails.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.CreationDisposition.CREATE_NEW
member.summary: Creates a new file. The function fails if a specified file exists.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.CreationDisposition.CREATE_ALWAYS
member.summary: Creates a new file, always.
member.remarks: If a file exists, the function overwrites the file, clears the existing attributes, combines the specified file attributes, and flags with FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE, but does not set the security descriptor that the SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES structure specifies.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.CreationDisposition.OPEN_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file. The function fails if the file does not exist.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.CreationDisposition.OPEN_ALWAYS
member.summary: Opens a file, always.
member.remarks: If a file does not exist, the function creates a file as if dwCreationDisposition is CREATE_NEW.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.CreationDisposition.TRUNCATE_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file and truncates it so that its size is 0 (zero) bytes. The function fails if the file does not exist.
member.remarks: The calling process must open the file with the GENERIC_WRITE access right.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_READONLY
member.summary: A file that is read-only
member.remarks: Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it. This attribute is not honoured on directories. For more information, see "You cannot view or change the Read-only or the System attributes of folders in Windows Server 2003, in Windows XP, in Windows Vista or in Windows 7".

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN
member.summary: The file or directory is hidden.
member.remarks: It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM
member.summary: A file or directory that the operating system uses a part of, or uses exclusively.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE
member.summary: A file or directory that is an archive file or directory.
member.remarks: Applications typically use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DEVICE
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set
member.remarks: This attribute is valid only when used alone

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TEMPORARY
member.summary: A file that is being used for temporary storage
member.remarks: File systems avoid writing data back to mass storage if sufficient cache memory is available, because typically, an application deletes a temporary file after the handle is closed. In that scenario, the system can entirely avoid writing the data. Otherwise, the data is written after the handle is closed.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SPARSE_FILE
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_COMPRESSED
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed.
member.remarks: For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_OFFLINE
member.summary: The data of a file is not available immediately
member.remarks: This attribute indicates that the file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, which is the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NOT_CONTENT_INDEXED
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ENCRYPTED
member.summary: A file or directory that is encrypted
member.remarks: For a file, all data streams in the file are encrypted. For a directory, encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_VIRTUAL
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_FIRST_PIPE_INSTANCE
member.summary: If you attempt to create multiple instances of a pipe with this flag, creation of the first instance succeeds, but creation of the next instance fails with ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED.
member.remarks: Windows 2000: This flag is not supported until Windows 2000 SP2 and Windows XP

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_NO_RECALL
member.summary: The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage. This flag is for use by remote storage systems.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: Normal reparse point processing will not occur.
member.remarks: CreateFile will attempt to open the reparse point. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational. This flag cannot be used with the CREATE_ALWAYS flag. If the file is not a reparse point, then this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_POSIX_SEMANTICS
member.summary: Access will occur according to POSIX rules
member.remarks: This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation
member.remarks: The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges. For more information, see "Changing Privileges in a Token".

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_DELETE_ON_CLOSE
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles.
member.remarks: If there are existing open handles to a file, the call fails unless they were all opened with the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode. Subsequent open requests for the file fail, unless the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode is specified.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_SEQUENTIAL_SCAN
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end
member.remarks: The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag should not be used if read-behind (that is, reverse scans) will be used. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING. For more information, see the Caching Behaviour section of CreateFile().

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_RANDOM_ACCESS
member.summary: Access is intended to be random
member.remarks: The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING. For more information, see the Caching Behaviour section of CreateFile()

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes. This flag does not affect hard disk caching or memory mapped files.
member.remarks: There are strict requirements for successfully working with files opened with CreateFile using the FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING flag, for details see "File Buffering".

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O.
member.remarks: When subsequent I/O operations are completed on this handle, the event specified in the OVERLAPPED structure will be set to the signalled state. If this flag is specified, the file can be used for simultaneous read and write operations. If this flag is not specified, then I/O operations are serialized, even if the calls to the read and write functions specify an OVERLAPPED structure. For information about considerations when using a file handle created with this flag, see the Synchronous and Asynchronous I/O Handles section of CreateFile().

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary: Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk.
member.remarks: For additional information, see the Caching Behaviour section of CreateFile().

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.SETXOFF
member.summary: Causes transmission to act as if an XOFF character has been received

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.SETXON
member.summary: Causes transmission to act as if an XON character has been received.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.SETRTS
member.summary: Sends the RTS (request-to-send) signal

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.CLRRTS
member.summary: Clears the RTS (request-to-send) signal

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.SETDTR
member.summary: Sends the DTR (data-terminal-ready) signal

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.CLRDTR
member.summary: Clears the DTR (data-terminal-ready) signal

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.SETBREAK
member.summary: Suspends character transmission and places the transmission line in a break state until the ClearCommBreak function is called (or EscapeCommFunction is called with the CLRBREAK extended function code). The SETBREAK extended function code is identical to the SetCommBreak function. Note that this extended function does not flush data that has not been transmitted.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.ExtendedFunctions.CLRBREAK
member.summary: Restores character transmission and places the transmission line in a non-break state. The CLRBREAK extended function code is identical to the ClearCommBreak function

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_RXCHAR
member.summary: A character was received and placed in the input buffer

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_RXFLAG
member.summary: The event character was received and placed in the input buffer. The event character is specified in the device's DCB structure, which is applied to a serial port by using the SetCommState function.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_TXEMPTY
member.summary: The last character in the output buffer was sent

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_CTS
member.summary: The CTS (clear-to-send) signal changed state

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_DSR
member.summary: The DSR (data-set-ready) signal changed state

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_RLSD
member.summary: The RLSD (receive-line-signal-detect) signal changed state

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_BREAK
member.summary: A break was detected on input

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Kernel32.SerialEventMask.EV_ERR
member.summary: A line-status error occurred. Line-status errors are CE_FRAME, CE_OVERRUN, and CE_RXPARITY

member.summary: A ring indicator was detected

member.summary: A printer error occurred

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Marshalling.GetMultiSz(System.Char[])
member.summary: Gets a list of strings from a Win32 API MULTI_SZ type.
member.param: The blob of character data to convert from.
member.returns: A list of strings.
member.remarks: Getting the multiple strings is used in many different Win32 API, not just the registry. It iterates through the blob, separating strings by the NUL character. The end of the list has two NUL characters.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Marshalling.GetMultiSz(System.Char[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a list of strings from a Win32 API MULTI_SZ type.
member.param: The blob of character data to convert from.
The number of bytes returned for the blob.
member.returns: A list of strings.
member.remarks: Getting the multiple strings is used in many different Win32 API, not just the registry. It iterates through the blob, separating strings by the NUL character. The end of the list has two NUL characters.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.Marshalling.GetMultiSz(System.Char*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a list of strings from a Win32 API MULTI_SZ type.
member.param: The blob of character data to convert from.
The number of bytes returned for the blob.
member.returns: A list of strings.
member.remarks: Getting the multiple strings is used in many different Win32 API, not just the registry. It iterates through the blob, separating strings by the NUL character. The end of the list has two NUL characters.

member.summary: The specified ResourceManager object could not be opened, because it was not found.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTIONMANAGER_NOT_ONLINE
member.summary: The object specified could not be created or opened, because its associated TransactionManager is not online. The TransactionManager must be brought fully Online by calling RecoverTransactionManager to recover to the end of its LogFile before objects in its Transaction or ResourceManager namespaces can be opened. In addition, errors in writing records to its LogFile can cause a TransactionManager to go offline.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTIONMANAGER_RECOVERY_NAME_COLLISION
member.summary: The specified TransactionManager was unable to create the objects contained in its logfile in the Ob namespace. Therefore, the TransactionManager was unable to recover.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_NOT_ROOT
member.summary: The call to create a superior Enlistment on this Transaction object could not be completed, because the Transaction object specified for the enlistment is a subordinate branch of the Transaction. Only the root of the Transaction can be enlisted on as a superior.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_OBJECT_EXPIRED
member.summary: Because the associated transaction manager or resource manager has been closed, the handle is no longer valid.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_RESPONSE_NOT_ENLISTED
member.summary: The specified operation could not be performed on this Superior enlistment, because the enlistment was not created with the corresponding completion response in the NotificationMask.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_RECORD_TOO_LONG
member.summary: The specified operation could not be performed, because the record that would be logged was too long. This can occur because of two conditions: either there are too many Enlistments on this Transaction, or the combined RecoveryInformation being logged on behalf of those Enlistments is too long.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_IMPLICIT_TRANSACTION_NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: Implicit transaction are not supported.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_INTEGRITY_VIOLATED
member.summary: The kernel transaction manager had to abort or forget the transaction because it blocked forward progress.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTIONMANAGER_IDENTITY_MISMATCH
member.summary: The TransactionManager identity that was supplied did not match the one recorded in the TransactionManager's log file.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_RM_CANNOT_BE_FROZEN_FOR_SNAPSHOT
member.summary: This snapshot operation cannot continue because a transactional resource manager cannot be frozen in its current state. Please try again.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_MUST_WRITETHROUGH
member.summary: The transaction cannot be enlisted on with the specified EnlistmentMask, because the transaction has already completed the PrePrepare phase. In order to ensure correctness, the ResourceManager must switch to a write-through mode and cease caching data within this transaction. Enlisting for only subsequent transaction phases may still succeed.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTION_NO_SUPERIOR
member.summary: The transaction does not have a superior enlistment.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_HEURISTIC_DAMAGE_POSSIBLE
member.summary: The attempt to commit the Transaction completed, but it is possible that some portion of the transaction tree did not commit successfully due to heuristics. Therefore it is possible that some data modified in the transaction may not have committed, resulting in transactional inconsistency. If possible, check the consistency of the associated data.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.Native.Windows.WinError.ERROR_TRANSACTIONAL_CONFLICT
member.summary: The function attempted to use a name that is reserved for use by another transaction.

member.summary: Transaction support within the specified resource manager is not started or was shut down due to an error.

member.summary: The specified file miniversion was not found for this transacted file open.

member.name: T:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream
member.summary: The SerialPortStream is a stream class to communicate with serial port based devices.
member.remarks:
This implementation is a ground up reimplementation of the Microsoft SerialPort class but one that is a stream. There are numerous small issues with the Microsoft .NET 4.0 implementation (and assumed earlier) that this class attempts to resolve.
For detailed information about serial port programming, refer to the site: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms810467.aspx
When instantiating.

member.name: F:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.InfiniteTimeout
member.summary: Indicates that no time out should occur.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor. Create a stream that doesn't connect to any port.
member.remarks: This constructor initialises a stream object, but doesn't assign it to any COM port. The properties then assume default settings. No COM port is opened and queried.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor. Create a stream that connects to the specified port.
member.remarks: This constructor attempts to bind directly to the port given. Properties assume the settings of the port provided. Exceptions may occur if the port cannot be opened.
member.param: The name of the COM port, such as "COM1" or "COM33".

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. Create a stream that connects to the specified port and sets the initial baud rate.
member.remarks: The stream doesn't impose any arbitrary limits on setting the baud rate. It is passed directly to the driver and it is up to the driver to determine if the baud rate is settable or not. Normally, a driver will attempt to set a baud rate that is within 5% of the requested baud rate (but not guaranteed).
member.param: The name of the COM port, such as "COM1" or "COM33".
The baud rate that is passed to the underlying driver.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,RJCP.IO.Ports.Parity,RJCP.IO.Ports.StopBits)
member.summary: Constructor. Create a stream that connects to the specified port with standard parameters.
member.remarks:
The stream doesn't impose any arbitrary limits on setting the baud rate. It is passed directly to the driver and it is up to the driver to determine if the baud rate is settable or not. Normally, a driver will attempt to set a baud rate that is within 5% of the requested baud rate (but not guaranteed).
Not all combinations are supported. The driver will interpret the data and indicate if configuration is possible or not.
member.param: The name of the COM port, such as "COM1" or "COM33".
The baud rate that is passed to the underlying driver.
The number of data bits. This is checked that the driver supports the data bits provided. The special type 16X is not supported.
The parity for the data stream.
Number of stop bits.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.Version
member.summary: Get the version of this assembly (or components driving this assembly).
member.value: The version of the assembly and/or subcomponents.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.PortName
member.summary: Gets the port for communications, including but not limited to all available COM ports.
member.remarks:
A list of valid port names can be obtained using the method.
When changing the port name, and the property UpdateOnPortSet is , setting this property will cause the port to be opened, status read and the port then closed. Thus, you can use this behaviour to determine the actual settings of the port (which remain constant until a program actually changes the port settings).
Setting this property to itself, while having UpdateOnPortSet to has the effect of updating the local properties based on the current port settings.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.GetPortSettings
member.summary: Update properties based on the current port, overwriting already existing properties.
member.exception: Serial Port already opened.
member.remarks: This method opens the serial port and retrieves the current settings from Windows. These settings are then made available via the various properties, BaudRate, DataBits, Parity, ParityReplace, Handshake, StopBits, TxContinueOnXoff, DiscardNull, XOnLimit and XOffLimit.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.Open
member.summary: Opens a new serial port connection.
member.exception: This object is already managing a serial port connection.
SerialPortStream is disposed of.
member.remarks:
Opens a connection to the serial port provided by the constructor or the Port property. If this object is already managing a serial port, this object raises an exception.
When opening the port, only the settings explicitly applied will be given to the port. That is, if you read the default BaudRate as 115200, this value will only be applied if you explicitly set it to 115200. Else the default baud rate of the serial port when its opened will be used.
Normally when you instantiate this stream on a COM port, it is opened for a brief time and queried for the capabilities and default settings. This allows your application to use the settings that were already available (such as defined by the windows user in the Control Panel, or the last open application). If you require to open the COM port without briefly opening it to query its status, then you need to instantiate this object through the default constructor. Set the property UpdateOnPortSet to and then set the Port property. Provide all the other properties you require then call the method. The port will be opened using the default properties providing you with a consistent environment (independent of the state of the Operating System or the driver beforehand).

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.OpenDirect
member.summary: Opens a new serial port connection with control if the port settings are initialised or not.
member.exception: SerialPortStream is disposed of.
Serial Port already opened
member.remarks:
Opens a connection to the serial port provided by the constructor or the property. If this object is already managing a serial port, this object raises an exception.
You can override the open so that no communication settings are retrieved or set. This is useful for virtual COM ports that do not manage state bits (some as some emulated COM ports or USB based communications that present themselves as a COM port but do not have any underlying physical RS232 implementation).
If you use this method to avoid setting parameters for the serial port, instead only to open the serial port, you should be careful not to set any properties associated with the serial port, as they will set the communications properties.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.IsOpen
member.summary: Gets a value indicating the open or closed status of the SerialPortStream object.
member.remarks: The property tracks whether the port is open for use by the caller, not whether the port is open by any application on the machine.
member.value: if the serial port is open; otherwise, . The default is .

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.Close
member.summary: Closes the port connection, sets the property to . Does not dispose the object.
member.remarks: This method will clean up the object so far as to close the port. Internal buffers remain active that the stream can continue to read. Writes will throw an exception.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.GetPortNames
member.summary: Gets an array of serial port names for the current computer.
member.returns: An array of serial port names for the current computer.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.GetPortDescriptions
member.summary: Gets an array of serial port names and descriptions for the current computer.
member.remarks:

On Windows 7, this method shows to return normal COM ports, but not those associated with a modem driver.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.ReadTimeout
member.summary: Define the time out when reading data from the stream.
member.remarks:
This defines the time out when data arrives in the buffered memory of this stream, that is, when the driver indicates that data has arrived to the application.
Should the user perform a read operation and no data is available to copy in the buffer, a time out will occur.
Set this property to for an infinite time out.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.ReadBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the SerialPortStream input buffer.
member.remarks:
Sets the amount of buffering to use when reading data from the serial port. Data is read locally into this buffered stream through another port.
The Microsoft implementation uses this to set the buffer size of the underlying driver. This implementation interprets the ReadBufferSize differently by setting the local buffer which can be much larger (megabytes) and independent of the low level driver.
member.exception: An attempt was used to change the size of the buffer while the port is open (and therefore buffering is active).

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.ReceivedBytesThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of bytes in the read buffer before a DataReceived event occurs.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.BytesToRead
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes of data in the receive buffer.
member.remarks:
This method returns the number of bytes available in the input read buffer. Bytes that are cached by the driver itself are not accounted for, as they haven't yet been read by the local thread.
This has the effect, that if the local buffer is full (let's say that it is arbitrarily picked to be 64KB) and the local driver also has buffered 4KB, only the size of the local buffer is given, so 64KB (instead of the expected 68KB).

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.ReadTo(System.String)
member.summary: Reads a string up to the specified text in the input buffer.
member.remarks:
The ReadTo() function will read text from the byte buffer up to a predetermined limit (1024 characters) when looking for the string . If is not found within this limit, data is thrown away and more data is read (effectively consuming the earlier bytes).
This method is provided as compatibility with the Microsoft implementation. There are some important differences however. This method attempts to fix a minor pathological problem with the Microsoft implementation. If the string is not found, the MS implementation may modify the internal state of the decoder. As a workaround, it pushes all decoded characters back into its internal byte buffer, which fixes the problem that a second call to the ReadTo() method returns the consistent results, but a call to Read(byte[], ..) may return data that was not actually transmitted by the DCE. This would happen in case that an invalid byte sequence was found, converted to a fall back character. The original byte sequence is removed and replaced with the byte equivalent of the fall back character.
This method is rather slow, because it tries to preserve the byte buffer in case of failure.
In case the data cannot be read, an exception is always thrown. So you may assume that if this method returns, you have valid data.
member.param: The text to indicate where the read operation stops.
member.returns: The contents of the input buffer up to the specified .
member.exception: Data was not available in the timeout specified.
Device Error (e.g. device removed).

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.ReadExisting
member.summary: Reads all immediately available bytes.
member.remarks:
Reads all data in the current buffer. If there is no data available, then no data is returned. This is different to the Microsoft implementation, that will read all data, and if there is no data, then it waits for data based on the time outs. This method employs no time outs.
Because this method returns only the data that is currently in the cached buffer and ignores the data that is actually buffered by the driver itself, there may be a slight discrepancy between the value returned by BytesToRead and the actual length of the string returned.
This method differs slightly from the Microsoft implementation in that this function doesn't initiate a read operation, as we have a dedicated thread to reading data that is running independently.
member.returns: The contents of the stream and the input buffer of the .

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.DiscardInBuffer

member.remarks: This function will discard the receive buffer of the .

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Check if this stream supports writing.
member.remarks: Supported so long as the stream is not disposed.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.WriteTimeout
member.summary: Define the time out when writing data to the local buffer.
member.remarks:
This defines the time out when writing data to the local buffer. No guarantees are given to when the data will actually be transferred over to the serial port as this is dependent on the hardware configuration and flow control.
When writing data to the stream buffer, a time out will occur if not all data can be written to the local buffer and the buffer wasn't able to empty itself in the period given by the time out.
Naturally then, this depends on the size of the send buffer in use, how much data is already in the buffer, how fast the data can leave the buffer.
In case the data cannot be written to the buffer in the given time out, no data will be written at all.

member.name: P:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.WriteBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the serial port output buffer.
member.remarks:
Defines the size of the buffered stream write buffer, used to send data to the serial port. It does not affect the buffers in the serial port hardware itself.
The Microsoft implementation uses this to set the buffer size of the underlying driver. This implementation interprets the WriteBufferSize differently by setting the local buffer which can be much larger (megabytes) and independent of the low level driver.
member.exception: An attempt was used to change the size of the buffer while the port is open (and therefore buffering is active).

member.summary: Clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be written to the underlying device.

member.name: M:RJCP.IO.Ports.SerialPortStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write the given data into the buffered serial stream for sending over the serial port.
member.param: The buffer containing data to send.
Offset into the array buffer where data begins.
Number of bytes to copy into the local buffer.
member.exception: Not enough buffer space was made available before the time out expired.
Object is disposed, or disposed during flush operation.
buffer was provided.
Negative offset or negative count provided.
Offset and count exceed buffer boundaries.
Serial port not open.
Serial Port was closed during the flush operation; or there was a device error.
member.remarks:
Data is copied from the array provided into the local stream buffer. It does not guarantee that data will be sent over the serial port. So long as there is enough local buffer space to accept the write of count bytes, this function will succeed. In case that the buffered serial stream doesn't have enough data, the function will wait up to milliseconds for enough buffer data to become available. In case that there is not enough space before the write time out expires, no data is copied to the local stream and the function fails with an exception.
For reliability, this function will only write data to the write buffer if the complete set of data requested can be written. This implies that the parameter be less or equal to the number of bytes that are available in the write buffer. Equivalently, you must make sure that you have a write buffer with at least allocated bytes or this function will always raise an exception.
